content: I’m sorry, but no. I am so tired of seeing this kind of deflection from the real issue, which is a combination of poor choices, both by provider and consumer, coupled with a societal issue that says “Hey, it’s okay. You’re just a victim here.” No, you’re not. You’re no more a victim than my friend Bob, who, at the age of fifty, now realizes he has to correct a lifetime of poor choices if he wants to see age fifty-one. He is morbidly obese and plans his entire day around the next meal, then wonders why it’s so difficult to get up and down stairs. His heart rate jumps just crossing the room. Your “participation medal!” attitude would tell him, “That’s okay, just take the elevator,” when the problem is he should have been taking the stairs all along. No, it’s not just exercise and it’s not just diet, and I get that. But if you’re going to suddenly claim you’re “genetically pre-disposed”, then I will tell you straight up that if you know the problem, that gives you a starting point to find the solution. If you know you’re “genetically pre-disposed” to do something not in your best interest, then you find a way of working around that. Otherwise, sorry, you have no one but yourself to blame. Yes, what the bride’s mother said was insensitive. But I’d posit that we didnt hear the whole story — how much self-sabotage did the bride do to herself to miss the mark? Serious weight loss is not for the faint of heart, you know that. It’s going to be difficult and harsh — but considering the alternatives, it’s worth making the effort before it freaking kills you. Your choice.
